 - OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) Program (1910.119) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.
 - OSHAs Emergency Action Plan Regulation, 29 CFR 1910.38(c).
 - OSHAs Storage and handling of liquified petroleum gases, e-CFR 1910.110(h)

3.	The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 

Safety and Environmental is the #1 core value of our company with a program called Goal 100%. We strive to work each job and each day 100% injury and accident free. This is supported by Critical Safety Behaviors, also known as our Golden Rules, which govern and guide us in our daily work activities:

 - Situational Awareness
 - Safety Process
 - Energy Isolation
 - Control of Work
 - Emergency Planning
 - Transportation Safety
 - Electrical Safety
 - Hazardous Materials Management
 - Fitness for Duty
 - Working at Height

At Texas International Terminals (TxIT), the safety of our employees, contractors, customers, neighbors, and the environment are a central focus and a core business value. Reducing the impact of our operations on the environment is also a priority. TxIT is committed to achieving Health, Environmental, Safety and Security (HESS) excellence throughout the organization. 
 
1.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 

TxIT management demonstrates its commitment to safety and environmental performance excellence by agreeing to correct in a timely manner hazards identified through self-inspections, employee reports, accident investigations, Facility Siting Studies, hazard and operability (HAZOP) studies, or any other means with interim protection and or mitigation as necessary. We provide the results of self-inspections and accident investigation to our employees through safety stand downs, town hall meetings, and monthly leadership meetings. We continuously seek areas for improvement and ways to raise our employees' level of awareness regarding all aspects of safety, health, and environmental performance.

2.	Facility and Regulated Substances Handled

The company started construction on a crude process unit in 2019 to produce Marine Grade Fuels. With this addition, there was a need to capture liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) produced from the unit.  The captured LPG will be stored in two, 45K Gallon ASME pressure vessels equipped with LPG tanker truck loading facilities.

The LPG storage and loading area is built to store and transfer LPG.  The LPG is delivered, via a 4-inch mixed LPG supply pipeline to the LPG Station from the onsite Crude Processing Unit, operated by Texas International Refining Company (TIRCO). Vapor recovery is provided by the use of a 4-inch line.
